Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genomics of Hybrid Sterility & Speciation in the Anopheles gambiae Species Complex
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate genetic mechanisms driving speciation in a group of mosquitos known to transmit disease. In this group of mosquitos the number of different species has traditionally been underestimated because, while indistinguishable in appearance, the group is actually comprised of multiple genetically distinct species. Despite their importance to humans little is known about how these species arose. This project addresses three questions in mosquito genetics. First what genes are responsible for reproductive isolation between the species? Second, how do those genes diverge across time leading to speciation? And third is the pattern of change between two species consistent across different pairs of species? Several of these species are the major vectors of human malaria in sub-Saharan Africa. In addition to helping us understand the genetic process that creates biological diversity, this project therefore has additional societal benefits as it may help in the development and implementation of novel genetic vector control measures by, identifying genes causing sterility in mosquitoes.

The name Anopheles gambiae is actually associated with a species complex of eight genetically distinct but recently diverged species that cannot be identified based on morphology. The complex is an important study system for the field of speciation genetics because species in the complex exhibit a wide range of genetic divergence, including partially isolated sub-species. Therefore this species complex allows these researchers to study speciation as it unfolds. When different species of the complex hybridize, the male offspring are sterile and females are fertile. If a hybrid female mates with a male of either parental species, the resulting second-generation hybrids exhibit varying levels of sterility due to genetic incompatibility. This allows genomic mapping of the causes of sterility through sequencing of many backcross offspring. This study will thereby map regions of the genome that cause male and female sterility in backcross hybrids between two species (An. gambiae and An. quadriannulatus). Combined with existing data on male and female sterility in backcross hybrids between An. gambiae and An. arabiensis this data will determine if the same genomic regions cause sterility across different species pairs. By comparing the patterns of divergence and their causes across multiple species pairs the research will increase our understanding of the factors driving speciation in an important group of animals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant examined how post-zygotic reproductive isolation evolves in the context of a recently diverged species complex. Previous work in the Anopheles gambiae species complex of malaria mosquitoes identified genomic regions that are responsible for male and female sterility in hybrids between two malaria vectors An. coluzzii and An. arabiensis. The goals of this project were to (a) identify regions of the An. coluzzii genome that result in male and female sterility when introgressed into a An. quadriannulatus genetic background (aims 1 and 2), and (b) compare these regions to those that cause sterility between An. coluzzii and An. arabiensis (aim 3). This experimental design allowed us to address a long-standing question in evolutionary genetics: When species diverge, does the rapid evolution of genes in one species contribute to genetic isolation with multiple, closely related species? To address this question, we used a high throughput genotyping approach and performed a quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis to identify genomic regions responsible for sterility in An. coluzzii x An. quadriannulatus hybrids.

 

We identified a large effect of the X chromosome on male hybrid sterility. This is not entirely surprising because males only have a single copy of the X chromosome, and recessive sterility genes on the X impact fertility in male hybrids, whereas those on the autosomes do not. This could mean that sterility genes tend to be recessive. Alternatively, our results could imply that genes on the X chromosome tend to evolve more rapidly than those on autosomes. A comparison with results from female hybrids (analysis in progress) will allow us to distinguish between these two explanations. Additionally, we identified regions on the autosomes that contain genes that contribute to sterility in hybrids. As expected, no recombinant X chromosomes were recovered in backcross individuals. This is consistent with previous genetic mapping results in this species complex, which show that the Xag chromosomal inversion in An. gambiae and An. coluzzii suppresses recombination with non-inverted X chromosomes in sister species of the complex. This suppression of recombination has likely facilitated the evolutionary divergence of genes on this chromosome, exacerbating its large effect on hybrid sterility.

 

The location of sterility genes overlaps partially with those that cause sterility in another hybrid within the complex. This suggests that at least some of the An. coluzzii genes that cause sterility in hybrids of this species with An. arabiensis also cause sterility in hybrids with An. quadriannulatus. We identified 23, sex-biased genes within this region that are significantly mis-expressed in An. coluzzii x An. quadriannulatus hybrid males in comparison to both parental strains. Interestingly, 16/23 genes show over-expression in comparison to the parental strains, whereas seven genes show under-expression in comparison to one or both parental strains. Five of these genes have functions that are obviously related to reproduction, with three genes tied to sperm production. These three genes are therefore promising candidate genes for causing reproductive isolation in hybrids between these malaria vectors.
